title: What is the Benn Act? How Boris Johnson may be forced to delay Brexit
text:

Boris Johnson's pledge to get Britain out of the EU by October 31 could be left in tatters - despite agreeing to a new deal with Brussels - all because of one piece of legislation - the Benn Act.

On Saturday MPs are set to vote on that deal - and the indication is that the vote could be incredibly close.

For the PM this could be his final chance to make sure Brexit can take place on time and with an agreement.

Mr Johnson needs the support of around 320 MPs to pass the deal.

But if Parliament does not support it, Mr Johnson is forced under the Benn Act to request a further Brexit delay from the EU.

So here is everything you need to know about the Benn Act and how it effects Brexit.

(Image: AFP via Getty Images)

What is the Benn Act?

Known formally as the EU Withdrawal (No.2) Act, it is a law passed by MPs which is designed to stop Boris Johnson from dragging the Britain out the EU if he fails to agree a deal.

It is named after the Labour MP Hilary Benn who spearheaded its passage through Parliament earlier this year.

It came about because Parliament feared that Boris Johnson would let the UK crash out of Europe without a deal.

What does it do?

It requires the Government to either reach a deal - or gain Parliament's approval for leaving without a deal by October 19.

If the Government can't meet this requirment then it demands that the Prime Minister write to the EU to request another extension.

The date for this extension, as suggested in the bill, would be 31 January 2020.

If the EU suggests another date then the legislation requires the Prime Minister to accept this - unless the Commons votes against the proposed date.
